pros: Good place to work at
cons: None really all good there

pros: In my assessment, the CEO and executives demonstrates a willingness to actively engage with their employees and foster transparency in their efforts to incorporate employee feedback. Notably, the company's town hall meetings offer a platform for candid inquiry and open dialogue. Additionally, Grab displays a commendable level of flexibility and responsiveness to employee needs and requests, with a clear emphasis on prioritizing employee well-being, including mental health. Especially, my team culture fostered a positive atmosphere in which employees are kind and considerate, expressing appreciation and offering constructive feedback to help others grow without causing negative feelings. Such behavior contributes to a supportive and respectful work environment that values employee development and well-being.
cons: The job could be demanding and potentially stressful, especially when balancing additional responsibilities on top of one's own tasks. It's important to take a proactive approach to demonstrate one's skills and make oneself visible to senior management to advance and gain recognition within the organization. The workload and project impact can vary among teams, contributing to the level of stress experienced in the role. Despite these challenges, the company does try to prioritize employee well-being.

review_title: Dynamic environment with great learnings but
pros:
1. Dynamic product (always evolving, new verticals/ideas all the time)
2. Good top down culture (CEO is a good man and instills good values)
3. Lots of learning opportunity since it's a super app and the infrastructure is huge
4. Good CI, workflow clearly defined, internal tools are decent
5. Devs can move across teams quite easily, managers exercise flexibility
6. Appraisals are fairly carried out with objectivity (judged by impact of work) and little play on politics
cons:
1. Some products are complex with rampant bugs
2. Engineers will do a shift (7 days) of on-call duties usually once every month (can be stressful)
3. Projects are touched by many hands (people come and go) and code usually contains dead, deprecated, over-engineered, hard to read/understand code (which engineers are afraid to touch in fear of breaking them) that leads to point 1 and 2.
4. Product managers command the direction and there's a strong emphasis on profitability and hence, things move very quickly, in terms of wanting to create new features (that may not actually create impact - but PM needs to show to the top they are innovating), and thus less emphasis is given on making code robust. And this leads to point 1 and 2.
5. Some engineers leave due to point 3, and it becomes a vicious cycle

review_title: My review is worth reading. Its the truth :)
pros:
I worked at GrabFin. I have about 10 years of work experience.

1. Motley Crew style. (Anyone goes, the manager will hire for what they need instead of what the role is about. Example: The manager is not tech savvy, so he/she will hire a tech background person to fill that void for a role that requires example stronger business domain knowledge.) Than they will throw the entire responsibility on you. (LOL)
2. No repercussions or accountability of any sorts for timeline slips, operational issues in general. (Weeeeee!) 
3. Free to do anything you want during office hours without anyone to check on you! (able to go and run errands as and when needed, and to attend to family needs. Weeee!) 
4. Don't need to be technically savvy or business savvy. Just need to know how to talk, and you can lead one stream and get an inflated title of Head. Probably about 5 - 6 yrs of relevant experience and you can be a head there! (Shiooook!!)
5. Tech team based in India, start work during SG lunch hours, goes for lunch when you get back and only start working for 2 hours a day ( 4 - 6pm SGT) with you. Therefore they only can look at 1 issue a day! (Shiok man, lesser for us do and just tell the boss that tech cannot deliver)
6. Tech team are like gold, need to keep them happy so they wont run away. So the bosses don't come down hard on them even if they just do minimal or don't do the work. 
7. Super high increment annually ( 10%ish) and Promotion every 2 years! (Where to find this man!) 
8. Travel is so frequent, if you like to brag on your social media with biz travel.. This is the place for you! 
9. You can focus on your side hustles, and jobs :):)
10. if you are lazy to learn new things, just come in here and do what they want you to. And you can probably live a stress free life and command a higher pay!

To conclude: If you are skilled, make sure you join at senior levels, you will get full flexibility, super duper nice increment and promotion and can do whatever you want there with minimal micromanagement due to the fact that dependency is on you to help them deliver. You will however face challenges working with people as they are like clowns who don't do what they doing except to talk rubbish and hold on to their life to their jobs so that they can make the next jump with a the fintech branding.
cons: Based on the above, is there even any cons?! I would say that if you are someone who is looking to learn more, passionate about your work and continue to build value to yourself and your career, than this is not for you unfortunately..

review_title: Challenging work in a supportive environment
pros:
- Work is challenging and you are unlikely to be bored or have time to be bored
- Leadership listens to the people and policies are employee-centric. Leadership also communicates well with the team and tries their best to be transparent, authentic, and honest
- Culture is collaborative and respectful
- Compensation and benefits are competitive
cons:
- The stress could mount and it is up to you to keep healthy boundaries for a good work-life balance
- Some people have been here for too long and it shows. There is a lack of drive or will to create new things / change
- Office location is remote; one needs to hop on a shuttle bus from either One North or Buona Vista MRT station to get to the office. Transport fees quickly pile up if you do not want to transfer multiple times. There are also limited food options in the vicinity, so lunch could get boring, expensive or both

f) Diversity is decreasing in HQ. People are inviting their friends with 1-2 interviews and become part of company. i have seen case where some good experience people got rejected because of favoritism.
g) Micro Management: Managers do mico management. 4H is just words.
h) High Politics: Your work and showcase is highly dependent on your age and relations with manager. How hard you try they will try to put down external factors such as age to suppress your impact.

review_title: A company that will be part of your life!
pros:
Grab, to the uninitiated, is like a beehive. always buzzing with energy and initiatives that one may get swept away. Given some time, this fast-paced culture will envelop you and you will surf the tides like a pro. 

I joined grab so I could work with diverse minds and extend myself professionally. There are many opportunities to prove your worth and the company also encourages internal mobility to steer away from routine and challenge individuals if they wish.
Your work is tied to goals for each quarter and you will be appraised based on that. So be clear on what needs to be done and do that.

* Excellent Flexi benefits
* HR team is one of the most dynamic and fun teams to engage with
* Engagement activities for fun and otherwise
* Innumerable learning opportunities
* Tech talks and Grab learn training to upskill
* Scope to do other things than what your role is intended to do
cons:
* Heavy meeting culture
* You are mostly on your own, Don't wait for a Fairy Grandmother!
*A few teams (mostly people) harbor judgments on individuals who fall short on their scale. Although they tell you to make as many mistakes as possible, every mistake is seen through a magnifying glass, which kind of sucks away the pleasure of working at Grab

review_title: Toxic peer competition culture for some teams
pros: Employee benefits are good, medical benefits, flexi-dollars, decent working environment. Managements are strives to care about employees
cons: Some team’s culture are little bit toxic. It involves lots of unnecessary competition over peers which made the whole team extremely busy. Although HR and managements have strives to create a good working environment which were very appreciated, the pressure from top-down made some teams (eg, my team) extremely toxic. Employees are forced to do more outside of their duties due to peer pressure and are forced to come to offices more than 3 days per week in the covid time even if the company only allows employees to come 2 days per week.

pros: Company provides a lot of perks and benefits, including a good insurance package that covers dependents and flexi claim system.
cons:
As a rapidly expanding company, you'll encounter teams that have been with the company for a long time and are not so open to new members joining.  They are used to their own way of working and have expectations set based on them for anyone joining the team.

I was quite unfortunate to have entered such team. Throughout my probation, I have diligently completed and provided timely support on the tasks that I'm aware I needed to complete. I even went the extra mile to help debug and fix others' errors and mistakes. I believe my biggest mistake was not asking for feedback because they didn't communicate or provide feedback to me on what I should be prioritizing until the last moments of my probation and use that as a reason not to move forward. I wasn't appreciated at all for my other contributions that I did for the team. 

As a result, I have to look for another job with EP and my pregnant wife is about to give birth soon. Pressure on me has been very hard to manage because I might not be able to take care of my family if I couldn't find a job within two months. Fellow jobseekers may know how difficult this is for a foreigner in Singapore. 

I could not speak for other teams but this is what I have gone through at Grab. I didn't receive the guidance I needed even though I'm new to the role and I didn't feel appreciated at all for my hardwork.

review_title: Great place to learn, but at times you may also feel lost
pros:
I have been working with Grab for more than 3 years and have gotten opportunity to work with best talents in Singapore. There is always lots of learning around you, I love randomly checking design drafts in engineering wikis and it itself gives you so much practical exposure compared to the bookish materials available on internet.
You will see lot of activities going on like events, initiatives, sessions and if you really engage in these things, you will find fun in your work place. On the org level, the company does make genuine efforts to maintain transparency and healthy office culture.
cons:
You may feel lost amongst the big org and wonder what to do next with your growth. There are career ladders defined to help but they often only end up as bullet points which lack clarity. Managers twist the ladder to their definitions. Career growth in terms of promotion is very subjective and hugely empowers managers to control this decision.
My manager is a good engineer, but he has lot of reportees under him and there is a lost touch leading to one feeling clueless of how to progress.

review_title: This is my balanced view after talking with several employee & alumni
pros:
- The package for tech is really good compared to any other companies
- The team that you are working for is really top notch quality, smart people
- Your direct manager are typically experienced and manage the team well
- The work life balance in "Transport" and "Food" is reasonable. GFG is an exception where people are forced to work longer than normal
cons:
Now the some part of "Pros" is actually the downfall of Grab

Aggressive culture
- The condition is too competitive and tend to be toxic. All 4 Grab alumni comparing our experience with previous employment and all agree that it's an "aggressive" culture where you never feel at ease
- Business and Tech tend to fight and just burnout from both sides
- Telling people about the real timeline will 100% of the time result in backlash and you are forced to tell the wrong timeline, just to miss it and get a backlash

Promotion problem
- With how high the qualities of the people are, it's making promotion choice a little hard. We notice that more than 50% of the promoted people, we disagree with. You can notice that when everyone is good, random trivial things are chosen as basis of promotion. The most noted are race (no, really, search for GFG managers in LinkedIn and you will understand), managing upward (you will notice the promoted people are the ones who do "less work" but "more talk")
- Short promotion ladder, there are only 3 promotion that can be guaranteed (G3-G5) while most people join as already G4 or G5

Org structure problem
- The way that Tech/Business is structured + aggressive culture makes it a bit unique. As a senior startup person, I will best describe this as "bank experience". The ratio between BO and PM is 1 to 1. The job of BO is just "overseeing all". In typical startup, business unit is either BD, Marketing, Ops with 1 BO which is at the very high level. However, in Grab, there are too many BOs which makes the communication a little inefficient

You will notice that most people leaving Grab because of this stress typically climb up quickly in another company. This is because Grab is a cluster of high quality, stressed & low career progression people

review_title: Grab Design - It’s a Rabbit hole
pros: Office location is good, new office location is pretty bad
cons:
I joined this company hoping that its a big brand who have a mission to solve people’s problem where design plays an important role. After working here it’s clear what they show it to the people of Singapore and SEA and what they think and the way they work internally is poles apart. It’s a Rabbit hole. 

It’s a company which is stuck in ‘creative rut’. There is no creative freedom because designs are controlled by your design leaders and product managers who have a very strong say in everything. Yes, everything. One of the 4H is Hunger and it’s a hunger for money. 

Work life balance is a mess here. You can see lots of reviews about this. My day starts at 9-9:30 am and ends at 8-9 pm. My average has been 12-15 hrs in past 3 years and I started to feel what am I doing and it’s not good for life and health. HR tends to ingnore these issues. Let’s say there is no HR here. People set too many meetings. They don’t even honour lunch time. It feels like a slave here. When you talk to your manager they say you need to manage your time and they blame you for their cultural mess. Which reults into stress and pressure because you need to prove yourself everyday here. Designers who are good with leaders/PM’s run the show which shows how the bad quality of design work is. Guess what all design leaders can’t see how is good and who is not.

People are very political and you can’t trust them. Most of the time they talk about you on your back. Promotions are not based on how you perform but how good you are at your PR skills. How good are you with your bosses also you need to be a chatterbox. I know a person who’s feedback wasn’t good but was promoted. If you are a chatterbox you win it’s ok if your design skills aren’t great or your don’t deliver the quality. Design heads are fine with this because that's how they are also. All design leaders wants is just the visibility nothing else. None of the leaders has not demonstrated to me that Grab value design. New HOD doesn't deserve to be at the position. Working with her is very very hard. This person sounds emotion less, no empathy for team members and sounds very rude most of the time. Before these new HOD’s design team used to be much better. Current design leaders are a not leaders. Nothing seems to be moving here. It’s mess and no one knows what’s going on and how to fix. Dirty politics and favouritism played by design managers and HOD’s. All design and product leaders have created a culture which is not positive. Design leaders and managers are busy in builidng their own profile and enjoying their life and money. Its the designers who are struggling a lot and thats why every month designers are leaving. Company don’t want to understand why and how can they fix it. They are not interested in fixing but showing that they bring impact. But where is impact? Why its not visible to the design team? Design leaders/managers/product and the leadership is a Gang of Rude Arrogant Blabber mouth. Everyone works here just to impress one person and that's how chain of command works. If you are looking to join Grab and specially design team, my suggestion is AVOID or keep it as a last option. The cost of working here is too high.

review_title: A mostly fine place to work, with a bit of caveats
pros: In Grab, you get to work with the most exciting problems and some of them, you are hard-pressed to find elsewhere, if at all. You also get to experience first-hand technology stack that rivals even the best of companies out there. I know because personally after transitioned out of Grab, I found myself at ease due to familiarity with most of the technology/services that other reputable companies are also using. You also get to work in a fancy huge office with a nice view. Most teams here gets work-life balance. Most team leads are competent and people are both smart and friendly. You will be above-average compensated if you work on tech by Singapore standards. It's a very diverse company and there are mostly no discrimination on your gender, age or race. High management have a focus on being kind and other good values. Depending on which team you are in, you may also get to travel a lot (during pre-COVID times), since they have a lot of offices around South-East Asia. Last but not least, at Grab you will feel that your work is actually making a positive impact and you can see it with your own eyes and ears every time you walk out the door. There is real job satisfaction here.
cons: Aside from the above average salary in the region, there isn't much other benefits to speak of - don't expect free food the likes of Facebook/Google; don't expect OT pay, don't expect unlimited ice cream. Do expect to get mid-range "used" Laptop (they use MacBook Pro here for Software Engineers). And god forbid if you break it accidentally, you get to pay for the repair, except if your department head agrees to absorb it. Aside from the occasional freebies and ice cream, don't expect any freebies that are regular - except for maybe drinks etc. Culture-wise, it's also average - there are no coaches and I get the sense that the company isn't willing to go the extra mile to invest in your well-being. Although your mileage may vary, generally company is pretty stingy when it comes to promotion and increments. Whenever there are questions about benefits during townhall, company will reiterate how they are already doing above average (which is true) and tell grandfather stories about how early grabbers gets much less and work much more. In terms of the office environments, even though you get to enjoy the view, you get sub-standard desk (no standing desks) and chair to go along with your old and slow laptop.

review_title: Politically charged work environment with minimal focus on engineering excellence
pros: Grab offers reasonable compensation in SE Asia and has some employee-friendly policies. A few of the engineers are technically competent, helpful, and demonstrate a collaborative attitude.
cons:
The primary driver of Grab's growth was the abundance of VC funds, which facilitated promotions and marketing campaigns targeted at driver-partners and customers. Grab acquired Uber's SE Asia operations because of Softbank's support, and they were the principal investor in both the companies. Uber's technology platform is superior, and its operations management methodology is better than Grab by many orders of magnitude. Browse to the public Github repos of Uber and Grab to get a better idea. 
The work-environment in Grab remains very politically charged. There are hordes of engineers who are incompetent but get promoted to G5 or G6 solely based on "good relations" with their reporting managers.
During my stint at Grab, I have across multiple instances in which a team of engineers would attempt to reinvent the wheel. A group built a documentation microsite using Hugo instead of using an existing system like Confluence (Wiki). There was yet another group that developed a mock-server, instead of using WireMock or MounteBank. Furthermore, the Engineering Lead was blissfully unaware of these open-source tools. Finally, this custom mock-server was buggy, painful to use, and did not have a single useful feature. 
The application codebase is bloated and is full of unsound (if not outrightly bad) engineering practices. The situation is so dire that Android Studio is unable to load the application codebase. The official recommendation on one of the documentation microsites is to use an alternate code editor (vi or vscode). Furthermore, you won't be able to build the codebase on your local machine, and the only way you can test your code is to use CI or to use remote infrastructure using Mainframer. 
The processes that are in place make engineering teams feel worthless and actively infantilize engineers and individual contributors. A manager has to approve almost each and everything, even something as trivial as internally publishing a code-labs (guided tutorial) or a video presentation on a component that you have designed and developed.

review_title: Great Company People Who Are, and Wish to Remain Single

cons:
- No semblance of work life balance - if I can give 0 stars I would. Seriously. Enjoy working till 4am in the morning? Enjoy it so much that you work the same amount even during weekends? Hate meeting up with friends and family that you want to avoid them anyway possible? Don't want to see your child growing up or dislike any meaningful interaction with your spouse? Grab is the place for you!
- Overly focused on product diversification, without understanding what are the key things that makes them a success in the first place. The company is now at the stage where they are trying to diversify into as many areas as possible, in as little time as possible. 
- Ever wondered why the core functionality and design of the app is so poor compared to rival apps such as Uber and Hail-O? Because whatever limited resources they have are being put to new products, and everyone is stretched beyond their limit. Core app functionality and experience be damned.

review_title: Interesting place to work in - get ready for a ride of your lifetime
pros:
Work with passionate team mates who are in for improving and impacting lives in SEA 
Much freedom - can depend on the team you are in, but most managers are nice
Benefits better than most startups - Leave, rides, food, etc
Great place to beef up your resume - What you do in 1 year at Grab can possibly suffice what others do in 3 years elsewhere
Great place to enhance your career if you're a talker and enjoy politics
Work-life balance: can be achieved if you delegate well / don't really care
cons:
Its messy, typical of a startup - yes, but when the top is only concerned about growth. and they forget about retaining people until each resigns.
Fast-paced - yes we like it fast, but the run has and will possibly be endless
Top-down approach - projects/decisions/tech may not be what the team would work best on
They say and look like they listen (surveys are sent out regularly) but you will realise they don't since nothing really changes.. after a while. 
Work-life balance: Work never ends. Emails don't either. People work when they are on leave. You can bring your work home but it will never be completed, resulting in either your family get upset with you or you're single and your parents don't need your time.
Political - Its hurting when the battling is internal.

review_title: Trying to build a solid Engineering Culture
pros:
- Truthfully one of the best places in Singapore right now as a junior (0-2 years experience) to land a job , especially in the backend team. Chance to work on interesting regional roll-out products
- Actually being treated like a human and having the chance to influence and make decisions that affect business purposes.
-Culture wise there is now a very open conversation about levels and career path. We were welcome to participate in that 
- Everyone in Engineering works on the same floor, there are good Managers who can lead without aggression and diverse team makes a fun workplace
- There is crazy youthful energy on the Engineering floor, everyone is so motivated it's hard to fall behind
cons:
- Work life balance, some people have too many responsibilities and no source of help, the only way is to understand how to treat employees before they burn out or are in a deep dark valley where they feel they cannot be helped.
- Legacy people from old school companies should not be hired in management team as decision makers.

review_title: A place to do impactful work and make a real difference
pros:
- Clear OKRs given and autonomy to do the work  
- Great org/team culture, with many smart, hardworking yet very humble people
- Feedback is taken seriously, whether through 1:1s or surveys, as changes are made, slowly but surely (maybe not always the right outcome, but effort is evident)
- SME sized org with a startup mindset, still so much work to be done and it's a great place for folks who love to create/build new products/processes
- A social enterprise company that truly believes in changing the livelihoods of the millions of people in SEA
cons:
- Senior management do not know what is really happening on the ground until it's too late, which puts them into fire fighting mode, trying their best to salvage what's already completely destroyed
- Despite their efforts to be more transparent, many things still are not, which may cause folks to feel unfairness (i.e performance appraisals, promotions)
- We grew too quickly as an org, that there is a clear divide between folks who have been here longer and the newbies; takes a lot of effort from the newbie to infiltrate existing cliques

job_title: Partner Marketing Manager in Woodlands New Town,
pros:
- Super smart colleagues that you can learn from (those from top colleges - Harvard, Oxford, INSEAD..)

- Flexible working arrangements (you can choose to work from home or anywhere, as long your tasks in hand are done)

- Decent compensation package (with monthly Grab credits for transport, food etc)

- YPIMP culture (Your Problem Is My Problem) hence your colleagues will be generally helpful to guide you through your daily tasks
cons:
- Super fast paced (if you're someone who needs a work-life balance, and not able to schedule your daily tasks efficiently, you might probably struggle. Things evolve really fast in the company that even your project that you're working on could go obsolete in a week's time, so you need to be comfortable with the constant change)

- YPIMP culture (can be a con too because if you do not know where to draw the line, you will be doing more than what you're supposed to and overburden yourself)

- Lack of employee benefits as a full-timer, in comparison with other tech companies like Facebook or Google.

pros: Decent paycheck, good work life balance
cons: A lot of nonsense titles and jobs. Hire people doing nothing

pros:
Good remuneration
Smart and fun colleagues
Great benefits
cons:
I am from the GrabFood team and that place is horrendous. People there are overworked, and plans change so fast that it kinda feels the heads are really just chasing the dollar.

If you love the Singapore work life culture (or should I say blend) this is the job for you. Revel in fun when your lunch, dinner, weekend and holiday times are completely burnt answering merchants. Suddenly, the remuneration doesn't seem too healthy looking at a wage per hour perspective.

Bosses are also part of the mess. You know you're in for lots of fun when the head honcho mentions a passing remark on the group chat (which is on 24 hours) and everyone springs to life answering and providing perspectives. The cherry on top - this happens on a Saturday night at like 9pm. Think of how this trickles downwards.

Sure, you get to learn a lot and see real changes, but this is at the expense of your time and sanity. 

I will only recommend these to people who are moving from a similar work schedule and subpar work culture. All the best, you'll need it.

review_title: Great pool of talents, can be better in utilizing them
pros:
- Lots of great talents from all over the world, especially in product, engineering, and design
- Benefit schemes are good, they provide flexible spending for Grabbers to freely utilize
- Opportunity to relocate to other offices and divisions, pretty flexible for enabling internal mobility
- There are cadence of town halls to maintain transparency across
cons:
- So many meetings, people love to sync up so much, may hamper productive hours
- Quite lots of bureaucracy for a startup, but technically the company is too big to be called a startup, need major revamp of process management
- Recruiting process took so long, benefits mentioned vs actual are not aligned
- Product, engineering, and design are still Singapore-centric, quite a hassle for those who are placed in Seattle, Beijing, Indonesia, Vietnam, and Bangalore to catch up
- No work-life balance
- Org. structure can be simplified

pros:
I made some really friends there, albeit through common suffering.

There were a small handful of full-timers who were nice and competent - got to give credit when it's due.
cons:
Mostly, the people working there are highly incompetent, both the temporary staff and the permanent staff.  A lot of people holding management roles completely disconnect with the customer service staff in the front lines. 

The worse incident was when one of the bosses actually arrange meetings with potential interviewees but make them wait for easily hours. He always cannot be found/reached by the front line workers, who are always the receiving end of anger.

When there are angry customers and clients who demand to speak to the manager,  many of the senior permanent staff avoid responsibility and tell the temporary staff to relay that the "manager" is not in. The fact that these senior staffs choose to hide in the backend and avoid responsibility shows a lack of capability.

Despite feedback to senior management about the lack of manpower, no action is taken and instead, we get feedback like "they need to learn how to manage it themselves". This kind of responses reflect how disconnected the senior staff are from what's happening on the ground.

pros: Growing company - good for younger employees to come in and get exposure.
cons:
Crazily long hours, Hectic with impossible target set - if you can't meet them, might be performance managed out. Constant fear of job stability with looming layoff in plan (under guise of weeding non-performance and saving on severance)

Fear of middle management (directs of C-suites), who only wants to be bearer of good news (for their appraisal) - and will continue to pressure their team to alleviate their own incompetence. First to cry = First to manage out.

pros: Office pantry for the perm staff is nice
cons:
Upper management is toxic and seems to only think that the temps want to slack off, they insist that we should take frequent breaks so we don't burn out but when said break is taken (5 min in 3 hours) they claim that we are slacking off
Upper management sleeps on the job while claiming that 'they were checking to see our performance'
Upper management wants to ban friendships in the workplace, which backfired completely
Upper management enjoys making baseless accusations while HR, fully knowing that it is baseless, just proceeds and does not bother to defend the employee
Low work morale
Sometimes cheats the system by saying that "my watch says its 7 oclock" when it is 7.30 so that they dont have to pay OT
Does not promote promising staff members with tons of experience but instead gets a new lady so that the team does not look sexist

review_title: Having fun solving complex social problems for in Southeast Asia
pros:
1. The problems that we are solving are complex e.g. traffic jams in SEA cities and personally I feel exciting
2. I love the challenge of the marketplace : balancing the demands of drivers and passengers. 
3. Social angle to the business : creating employment.
4. Company is diversifying into lifestyle e.g payments, finance, etc
5. Management which is open to feedback and changes.
cons:
1. Product culture is primarily business-driven. This is not a bad nor uncommon thing in other companies per se. But we do need to consider the trade-offs that we make when we are hacking against our system and app experience. And make those decisions with our eyes open. 
2. Fast headcount means that you may find yourself in a dynamic environment e.g. having to work with new people every week.  Not a bad thing, if you like fast pace and working in a diverse environment.  But bad if you are not adaptable and if you expect everything to be running SOP-ed.

review_title: Amazing work culture, friendly and helpful employees, challenging but achievable goals
pros:
I've interacted with a lot of employees due to the nature of my work, and only 1% have shown very very negative traits - the rest have been collaborative, positive, friendly, and genuinely nice. 

The work is very challenging and it forces you to really apply critical thinking processes to get tasks done.  My department is highly autonomous and does not micromanage - something I thrive in.

Facilities are clean, security is tight, welfare for employees are very generous. 

We have a 3 day onboarding program, and though its been months, my onboarding batch is still very tight and our sentiments are the same toward the company.
cons:
The organization chart is very very big and wide, so it might take some time to figure out who should you approach to for what vertical etc. 

Also, business needs are ever changing so being nimble and objective is key to staying afloat.

pros:
I've been at Grab for a while now and have seen the many challenges it has faced.

It is not a perfect company but it tries really hard to do the right thing, often in very difficult situations. The company has matured in a substantial fashion, and while there are certainly areas where it has to improve on, the trajectory is in the right direction.

Grab is unsurpassed in some areas:

a. Product/customer obsession. There is a reason its the unicorn it is. No other company in SEA shows the level of focus to customers that Grab does.

b. Excellent engineering. Engineering is rigorous and keeps setting higher standards.

c. Driven team. Everybody wants Grab to win, and this shows in teamwork and the push for excellence.

d. Surrounded by smart people.

e. Incredible cultural diversity. There are people from across the globe.

f. Excellent office, overlooking the sea.

g. Inhouse gym.
cons: Processes are getting refined to accommodate growth of the company

pros:
- can work from home 
- start time is flexible 
- some snacks and drinks in the pantry 
- free Grab rides / flexi benefits 
- founders are good people and care about south east Asia 
- nice offices and locations
cons:
- culture is not consistent across departments. HR often has blame culture and people do not have each others backs
- staff like to say they are very busy and work long hours to seem more hard working then others. Many are not genuine
- bias, you can be promoted if the big bosses like you (even when you do a bad job). If they don’t, you won’t (even if you do a great job).

pros:
1. Colleagues are all extremely talented- with top notch analytical, engineering, and data skills
2. Environment is enthusiastic, and energetic. New ideas are always welcome
3. Colleagues as well as management give credit where due. Good work is always appreciated and recognized
4. Company direction is clear, there is no ambiguity or delay in taking important decisions
cons:
Transportation is a challenging industry, and happens to be a cash heavy business. It's not easy for even the best player to be profitable soon.
That's probably the only con I can think about GrabTaxi

review_title: A great place to work (if you’re ambitious and enthusiastic)
pros:
- A productive, supportive, egalitarian environment and culture driven by the two founders.
- Very high caliber of people: smart, driven, ambitious and open-minded. 
- Very little politics.
cons:
- In order to support growth and generate more business, Grabbers typically don’t say no to new opportunities. That results in taking on a lot of projects with tight deadlines, and a poor work-life balance. Very typical for people to leave the office on time but then get back online and work until after midnight. Working on weekends is also a norm for mist functions.
- Benefits are not comparable to other tech firms.

review_title: Not A Good Time To Be In The Company
pros:
- You get a good brand on your CV.
- If you are lucky, you make a few good friends in the company.
cons:
- The company is no longer the same company when I first joined. When money was not a problem and tech-companies were all hyped out, life was, of course, good and morale was high.
- With recent developments in the tech world where IPOs are shelved and heavily-funded tech-companies on the verge of going bankrupt, you would expect Grab to be under a lot of pressure. Grab is the only company now that is going to help save the face of one of its biggest backers. You should know who and what I'm referring to.
- Expect pressure to trickle down from the top, and when you put human self-interests into the equation, expect toxicity to arise as well. The toxicity I am referring to will come in different forms. People getting disengaged, morale being extremely low, and generally people who are just looking out for themselves.
- The inadequacies of management are beginning to show during this troubled times when the race to profitability is the absolute priority now. When things are going good, managing the company and a team will definitely be easy, but everyone is being put to the test now and what a lot of middle-management and below staff have witnessed is nothing short of disappointing.
- A lot of the senior managers who joined the company were pulled-in by their previous colleagues, so there is definitely some form of corporate-nepotism which was OK at the start, but people are now realizing they are really not fit for the job. Unfortunately, some of them hold lead positions, and you'll often hear that Human Resources is mediocre which any current and former staff can attest to.
- Morale is extremely low in the company. Management is extremely good at painting a pretty picture and are good with words, but at the end of the day it counts for nothing.
- The company is running on staff with an average tenure of around 1.5 to 1.7 years, so this says a lot. There will always be people who are willing to take a pay-increment and enter the company to slog for a year or two, and then use the company brand to go to another bigger, more established, and more importantly profitable tech firm. Everything looks nice on the outside, but inside, it's a mess.
- Do not expect to be promoted unless you are willing to sacrifice everything else in your life for the company. Career progress is horrid here because of cost-cutting and there will always be people applying to join the company. Management does not map out your career path clearly for you here.
- Staff benefits are considered mediocre compared to industry standards because, again, becoming profitable is the focus. But you can't expect much when Human Resources are a joke in the company. Harassment cases are handled extremely poorly with HR telling the victim that their job is to protect the company first.

review_title: Burning Money in the sputtering SuperApp Rocketship
pros:
(1) Incorporating marginally better employee benefits and training after significant amount of low employee ratings and feedback from exit interviews.
(2) Some free snacks and sugary drinks + tea but all sourced cheaply from SEA due to cost controls
cons:
(1) Incompetent and/or ineffective management loyal from early days of Grab still remain in senior positions within the company.  Many are protected despite ineffectiveness
(2) More layering aka bureaucracy in the organisation hence more time is required to finalise decisions 
(3) Employee turnover becoming more significant but POPS does not disclose figures to staff.  Lack of recognition for work or effort in the company.
(4) Nepotism
(5) Annual merit increments and bonuses are low compared to similarly sized companies in technology sector.

An article which shows some insight into Grab yet with more insight on the dysfunctional culture would be more telling...

Article from Bloomberg written by Tim Culpan will help provide more context.

pros:
- Fantastic pantry
- Flexible working conditions eg. Listen music during work, chit chat
- Office hours 10 am to 7 pm (less crowded hours to take trains)
- Friendly colleagues and bosses
cons:
- Limited career advancement. Hard to convert from Part time to Full Time (rare job openings)
- Varying wages for different part time jobs that has the same requirements
- Laptop laggy and fragile 
- Tech people are not very friendly
- Vulnerable working system with little compliance or access control 
- Little training, Part timers training part timers 
- Clueless full timers 
- Too regular part timer rotation (every batch of new timers after a few months) 
- Blurry instructions
- Work given very manual 
- Might have minor politics

review_title: Was a great place to work but environment changing with growth.
pros:
Diversity at workplace. A lot of different nationality and different people to meet and work with.
Working with all latest tech stack.
Flexible timing.
cons:
Over time, culture is being affected with growth.
They don't value existing employee comparing new hire. New hire with less experience are joining with higher salary where old employee's salary is not adjusted or compensate. Disappointing that HR think existing employee poses no knowledge of salary structure and try to play with this.  Also different team has different structure of salary, even though, role is kinda similar.

pros: Lots of responsibility, fast moving, company cares a lot about customers and driver partners (doesn't always deliver - but does try its best)
cons: Your experience will be determined by who your boss/vertical head is. Some teams have a great culture of openness and meritocracy, others are bogged down by egos, infighting, and politics. If you are in the latter teams, don't expect HR to help, they will do only what they are told.

pros: Using some latest technologies, fast growing company but not a startup anymore.
cons: building brittle systems under the pretext of moving fast.  Lot of senior management has never worked on or built systems at this scale before.

pros:
tech stack provides opportunities for learning a lot of contemporary technologies.
gain deep AWS experience.

Transportation tech brings a lot of technical challenges - great to learn & exercise CS algorithms. Large Scale low latency real time ops also brings unique issues to on-demand tech. 

Regular Hackathons - encouragement from top management to prototype new stuff.

Overall good platform for entry level & senior engineers to build foundation for a career in cutting-edge product software development and testing.
cons: still a startup,so it can take a while for structured processes to be adopted end to end. But this could be a plus, depending on how you look at it -You can experiment with lots of new tech.

pros:
1. apparently market leader in car hailing, food delivery
2. had a lot of money support from SoftBank
3. prospect in finance has great potential 
4. some offices are physically great (eg Marina One)
cons:
1. technology is lower than expected for a company of this size and >7 years old. actually the level of technology management and speed of development is disappointing. Don’t see the spirits of pursuing quality or better solutions.
2. HR system is terrible. HR team seems totally incapable to evaluate people properly and put right people into right position. Every round of performance review leads to mass attrition. Managers also play a bad role in this, a lot of them don’t promote people according to contributions but based on favoritisms or as a part of their politics game.
3. Top leaders don’t seem to have a clear strategy thinking. They behave and talk like amateurs. Their words are not convincing in a lot of the internal communications.
4. High level managers (BU heads, TF heads) seems to be obsessed in politics than doing real contribution. Actually these big shots seems to be the biggest limiting factor in company development. Even some middle managers are diligent, they cannot change the bad impacts that higher leaders are doing, like unproductive strategies (superapp, AI), nonstop reorgs(during which some leaders are pushed out and power shifted to more incompetent leaders). 

You may wonder how come the company is still doing well if there are bad management? First, it’s money, this is a heavily money-driven market. Second, high quality employees keep joining the company attracted by the name, so they still get things done. but they don’t stay very long and they don’t realize their full potential. The company could have done much better.

pros: Great bosses and colleagues. Management is caring and allows me to try new things and experiment. The work we do impact millions of lives and my work is meaningful. I have the opportunity for career mobility is I choose but still happy where I am. Pay and bonus is good.
cons:
This isn't a place for the weak or inexperienced. If you are a non performer expect to be found out. 
The pace is fast and the work is hard and challenging.
There is no formal training programs so you either learn from your manager or learn on your own.

review_title: Looks good from outside but shabby from inside
pros: Grab is growing at a fast pace.Hence, you can expect to grow fast as well. However, this has many cons
cons:
One of the worst HR team I have experienced working with
Management expect for top 20 are inexperienced and incapable of handling the stress from the fast paced environment and it comes out on lower management

pros:
Opportunities for developers and builders to get large and meaty projects that can deliver amazing value to millions of people. 
Some talented developers who share a positive vision. (We lost a large number of really good developers, managers recently).
cons: Too many politicians (the political parties being Engg, Product, Data and Market Heads), Very little strategy (there is no end game in sight), the company has raised crazy sums of money at a nominal valuation...the options are not going to be worth anything to employees. The investors would have set conditions to take out their investments.

pros:
+ A lot of autonomy (and trust) to do things
+ Incredibly talented colleagues 
+ Move incredibly fast
+ Lots of challenges for personal growth
+ flexible working hours
+ Fantastic location in CBD 

I've been here for well over a year now and I love working in this company for the various reasons listed above. Grab is still really still a startup and we're figuring out a lot of things along the way from Product to Engineering and best practices, but that's where the fun and excitement is where you get to contribute your ideas and drive the implementation of it.

I also learned a lot each day from the very talented engineering colleagues that I work with, who are very friendly and do not hesitate to share knowledge - especially helpful and important when you're learning a new language like Go.

Overall, I'm having a great experience here at this company and seeing the various interesting projects that different team is working on, I'm very positive that the future will an exciting one and a fulfilling one for my career as an Engineer.
cons:
- Need more company outings
- Need more updates on company
- Work place could be more fun

I feel that we need to have more outings like bowling, cinemas, dinner to get to know one another better, especially people from other teams and departments. As we grow bigger, we also need to grow tighter so that no one would feel left out in the growth process.

There needs to be more updates on the company, what are the plans in store, exciting things that happened, new product launches, ventured into new cities etc.

Lastly, I also feel that the company could have more fun things in the office like ping pong table, pool table, or foosball table. Empty walls could be use for art, display of heatmap, interesting updates on the company etc

review_title: If you want to grow, this is the place.
pros:
Super talented people.
Environment in which one can focus and produce their best work without drama or organisational chaos.
Lots of opportunities to contribute and push yourself as much as you want. 
Not authoritarian, you feel like you can make stuff happen bottom-up.
People work hard but there is no expectation of people working overtime. 
Great diversity of people and very impressive balance of male-female.
Opportunities to experience all SE Asia markets. Travel.
cons: The atmosphere is more 'focused' and less playful. I think we need more of the later. But I don't think that comes with management. It comes from individuals making that happen.

review_title: Not a Tech company. A very different image on the inside.
pros:
Transport allowance
Great people
Work-life balance
Flexible working hours
cons:
Engineering standards are low but management believes otherwise
Engineers are mere code monkeys with no chance to explore their ideas
Work is neither high tech nor feats of engineering
Nothing much to learn for strong engineers as there aren't many senior engineers or too risk-averse to try out new technologies
Limited career growth as an individual contributor
Information is heavily guarded and teams are very silo-ed; lack of direction and everyone's doing their own stuff
Lots of upper management politics

pros: - Had the pleasure of meeting a few genuine and kind colleagues.
cons:
- HR processes are not great. Filed an HR complaint regarding a racist manager; barely any action was taken. Instead of creating a strong plan to tackle the issue, it was shrugged off. 
- Trying to portray themselves as one of the cool tech firms, but are not getting it right from the diversity and inclusion front. 
- No clear vision explained to the teams; things change at the blink of an eye and what you might have been working on tirelessly for a month will no longer exist in the next month.
- Quite a toxic environment overall.

pros: The opportunity to work in a mid-level startup. Free Grab rides to/fro work are a plus.
cons:
- Young capable managers who totally have no clue on people management. 
- Extreme micromanager, expects you to read her mind, and insults you when you cannot, to the extend of insulting the capabilities of my ex-company.
- Use threats to make things go their way.
- Insufficient subsidy and lack of commission to do telemarketing call; have to fork out own money for phone bills.
- Lack of job security. Constantly feared of being fired.
- Poor benefits compared to other startups.

review_title: A great culture as startup company for developers
pros:
- Good culture of start up environment. 
- You can meet a lot of excellent people and learn a lot of new technologies. 
- Good benefit as there are events, transportation perks, hackathon...
cons:
- Working long hour and sometimes very stress. 
- Team politics and some procedure is unmature.
- Some department planning is not so well, and growing online team too fast.

pros:
In the past, Grab got too much money from investors to explore differrent types of directions/businesses without transparent outcomes & tracking. 
In our team, several heads and leads spent time on communicating fantasy to Grab employees and to the world at expert level.
cons:
Company climate:  unsure if we deliver or burn money;  team members want to find a new job with the uncertainty and do what the big Head told in the meetings. 
The leaders encourage you to ask questions, the answers are often so politically correct and no one understands what is the real message or direction.

review_title: Best company I ever worked for
pros: A lot of problems to solve, not enough people to solve them, a lot of opportunities to learn and make a difference.
cons: A lot of communication over head. Senior management had a wide range in their capability, so choose your leader wisely within the organisation.

review_title: Working in a corporate support team.
pros:
Great culture and team spirit.  Colleagues are super helpful and they may appear busy but they will always lend you a hand.
Pantry is well-stocked if you need a snack in between meals.
Senior management are approachable and eager to hear your ideas and feedback.  They make efforts to engage with the people and this makes them truly grounded in real-life issues that we face when working.
cons: You need to know how to manage your time, and know your priorities.  If you dont have this skill, you could be overwhelmed without knowing.

review_title: Got burned out due to long work hour
pros:
- $100 taxi allowance per week, but new joiner now get less
- Smart people
- Happy hours
cons:
- Too much work. Again, long hour and very stressful. You will get  burned out.
- Most of people get to the new office. Some people are left with the old Cecil office with dirty fingerprint scan at door.
- Again, overtime, overtime, and overtime.

pros:
- Great talents to work with and willing to share their knowledge.
- Free lunch is awesome.
- Happy hour Friday evening.
cons:
- Pay less attention to the existing employees.
- Didn't plan well for what to do.
- ineffective work flow for team, unorganised (certain team)

pros: Incredibly challenging work environment with very smart people. Grab is in a unique position in the marketplace, and you get a chance to work on very impactful projects that can potentially shape the future of the region.
cons: Growth pains that plague a fast-moving startup and large MNCs. Creeping politics and internal strife due to the silo'd organization, where teams look after their own interests. Very chaotic working environment, perhaps shaped by the necessity to respond quickly in a rapidly changing marketplace. Can be depressing at times just dealing with people rather than getting work done.

review_title: Great place to work, learn and grow
pros:
- Great people
- Meaningful work - impacts people in the lowest strata of society, helping with social mobility
- Co-founders are very accessible,  approachable,  humble, and remain true to their original double bottom line vision (i.e. sustainable social impact)
- Growing rapidly, so there's always opportunities for personal career development. 
- The new Marina One office is amazing - great view of the coastline, and a gym in the office
cons: - No dental or optical benefits

review_title: Working in the legal team at Grab
pros: Exciting work and fast growing at a rapid speed.  Start up culture and everything is being done at a start up style. Performance management, your appreciation to the role etc.
cons:
Managers (legal) dont even know their legal basic fundamentals. Everything is for a temporary fix. Not sure how they qualify for such roles but thats the fact. You just need to bite the bullet and continue working if you can. 

You contributed above what you do in your role but they (managers) would not appreciate it. Well not their fault because they dont even know their own work fundamentals.

pros:
Pays higher than industry average.

Going to move to a fancy office site.

Plenty of talents hired. Good strong talented individuals.
cons:
No unanimous direction. Some thrives in chaos, others suffer in it.

Too many product managers each stating his/her product is key to company success. 

Low barrier to hiring in some positions. Makes you wonder why this person is hired/fit for the job.

review_title: Flexible but prepared to get axe if you don’t perform
pros: FT staff can claim Grab rides around $400. Great snacks and drinks at pantry and dressed-down 24/7 unless you have important meetings. Diverse culture with a good mix of staff from different parts of the world.
cons: You’re expected to perform or the risks of getting fired is very real. Not very structured and very often, you have to find your own way. Pay and bonus is not great.

pros:
Flexible working arrangement
Leadership has good business sense 
Work with smart colleagues 
Diverse and international team
cons:
Below the market compensation, considering the hours you are expected to work

Zero work life balance due to the lack of structure and process. A lot of initiative being launched haphazardly without a proper engineering and/or product testing, which lead to constant fire-fighting when the features crash

You are expected to work overtime and during the weekend to manage the chaos

Lack of career progression. As a grab pioneer, there seems to be a lack of career growth to move into mid-level and/or senior role.

Being branded as agile, innovative startup. However, the way of work is very traditional and highly political

review_title: Lots of Potential, Lots of Flaws
pros:
Huge Market
Leadership has good ideas and has business sense
Interesting people from varied backgrounds
cons:
No semblance of a work-life balance
LOTS of politics
Doesn't really work like a tech company - lots of old-fashioned middle management who sticks with antiquated processes

review_title: First Hired than harassed and than fired
pros:
free lunch on design Thursday
offsite trips
free grab rides
cons:
The interview process is pathetic ask question from the internet just to get the person on board.
Male lead starts physically harassed and when I get strict and keep the distance from him he fired me because of this.
Can not bear any good advice for there messay work
Chinese speaking culture don't want to give place anyone else.

review_title: Great Brand, good learning. Lots of work
pros:
Constant learning, empowerment for decision making. Feel a sense of accomplishment.
Fun people to work with. A very committed bunch.  
Never a dull moment - Go go go …
Working at Grab will  open doors for you.
cons:
Never a dull moment - 24/7 go go go…
Endless meetings, often last minute and some times unproductive 
Too many cross overs of project teams or cross departments doing similar work. 
Training opportunities were non existent when i was there.

pros:
I've been working at Grab for 20 months in the People Operations team. 
Every day poses new challenges, from understanding & assimilating to the fast-paced & high-performance culture, to navigating the extensive network of Grabbers and leadership across SEA, to learning about the tech start-up industry. 
It is an exciting time to be in this company and this industry and there are a lot of smart people to work with and learn from in the company.
cons: Performance goals and targets are constantly changing, so one has to keep improvising and adapting to constant changes.

review_title: Rapid, honest but rigorous interview process
pros:
- Interaction with accomplished yet humble people
- Exposure to senior leadership across the organization in the process
- Will move fast as long as you keep clearing each hurdle (had 5 interviews)
- Honest and open feedback during stages, as appropriate (talent team is on the ball)
- Transparency while discussing offer
- Key test: alignment with Grab vision, so please speak with a few Grabbers and introspect as you go through the process
cons:
- Don't expect a lot of structure
- Expect real life case studies to be shared and your reactions to them solicited

pros:
-Chance to experience fast growth company and thus, immense learning opportunity
- Opportunity to collaborate with multiple stakeholders
- Open structure whereby you are free to contribute or drive initiatives
cons:
- With fast growing company, comes the point whereby you need to be able to adapt and learn quickly, which may be a challenge to most people
- The open structure may lead to non-clear work responsibility 
- With the increase in size of the company, there needs to be more control and governance, this leads to structural change towards more corporate structure

pros:
- interesting work and what you do affects a lot of people
- good way to build your resume
- hiring a lot
- free grab rides
cons:
- political, everyone is looking out for themselves 
- can't disagree with your manager and when you do, told you don't know enough about the company
- expected to always put work before your life, you're not a team player if you can't

review_title: Great culture and nice people around. Fast paced and a good learning ground for anyone.
pros: Culture, people are good. Dynamic environment. Hybrid startup and corporate environment. It's a unique company growing in the region and it's rare to find one like this.
cons: Needs to get more structured in processes. Some closed circles amongst groups. Be open on talent and perceptions of these talents.

review_title: Hired, relocated, thrown without explanation the reason
pros:
Taxi bonus
Happy Fridays
Many nice people
cons: Inner politics, unprofessional management, micromanagement, very nice contract to get fired without explanation the real reason, do not trust any single word of your manager, do not plan your life with grab for long, do not rely on bonus and stocks, keep hand on pulse first year, do not trust people with whom you work, it is not friendly environment, people will be happy to fire you if you will start complaining that they are not doing their job properly.

review_title: Mixed feelings after some time at Grab
pros: No doubt, the premier reason is that the startup is constantly in the news which is both a pro and a con. However, you can be guaranteed that this helps generate some vibe around the firm.
cons: Contrary to the image that Grab gives off, it's work environment has a lot left to be desired. Company morale (at least to me) seemed stagnant and directions were often not felt like they were communicated clearly to all.

review_title: Alot of challenges and autonomy with some setbacks
pros: Great autonomy, given the chance to work on your own with little supervision assuming you can deliver the work
cons:
Have felt a lot of favoritism in this firm, might be department related but who knows?

Undeserving employees get rewarded over others who outperform them

review_title: Not a great place to be
pros:
A mixture of people from Amazon, Google and other top companies are there. Hence company has got a good brand name outside for sure. 

Unlimited snacks and beverages. 

One of the few companies offering higher salaries in Singapore. So while switching you are able to negotiate for higher offers.
cons:
Post interview process:

Grab was lethargic in handling the post interview process too. Once they confirmed the offer, I told them about another offer and asked to speed up next steps so that I could let the other company know or make an informed decision. But they were not even replying properly and behaved as if they are doing a favor by giving the offer. This is because of the superiority feeling that everyone in Grab has. However it is sheer arrogance.

After joining:

I interviewed for one role but just because they had an opening in another team they put in that team and the people in other teams themselves ridiculed this team. This gave me the realization that I had made a huge mistake joining Grab and not choosing the other offer. This showed the unprofessionalism of the people as well. This did not happen for me alone. This happened for many people actually. The environment itself looks pathetic, not just for one team but almost everyone I have spoken with. It's the most sad environment I have ever worked in. I was unhappy the entire time and depressed too because of joining Grab and I thought it was my mistake initially. But after seeing others, I realized that the founders, leadership, senior management have created this miserable environment and not bothered about it too.

Irony is that culture value deck asks people to be humble. However, a bunch of people I interacted with, were the most arrogant people I have ever met in life. Nobody knows what is humility or humbleness. Everyone is just trying so hard to prove others that they are the best. Well, what is the point in doing that? Instead they should focus on improving the app.

Reorg:

Almost every month there was a re-org. Well one of the culture values is disrupt or be disrupted. I think the some teams like SRE team took it literally for the team and decided to disrupt everyone every month or otherwise they "assumed" management will disrupt them. Literally there was re-org every few months and their leadership changed every few months. So there was no stability or reliability for the team itself. Ironic that this happened for SRE who are supposed to bring reliability for the services. This affected my service team too badly for sure.

Work and Culture:

Devops and Infra is the worst team here definitely. Internal politics is too much. They created SRE team for services, who are again just bunch of arrogant people, who are not really bothered about improving Grab. They just want to get promoted just because they think they deserve it, even if they have not done anything useful. That team is just a proxy to other devops and service teams. During issues, they do not do anything themselves. They plead others to fix and hope that it gets fixed. But still they seek credit for that by mentioning that in their performance reviews. 

People there are only interested in getting promoted. While wanting to get promoted is not bad thing, they want to get promoted badly that they will do only things that get them promotion or better rating and never implement anything. I have known people who got promoted just by talking alone endlessly or just writing proposal document and never implemented anything. Having read blog posts from other companies, the same thing was done by interns in other companies successfully and in Grab it was just a proposal document forever and still just for writing that and not implementing it, they get a huge rating. People speak like they moved mountains when in fact they just changed some metadata in a web console.

I have heard people complaining so much about others getting promoted. That is the culture now. Everyone wants to beat others and become highest Grab levels in career ladder but never once I heard anyone really talking about fixing issues for the customers or drivers.

Promotions:

Anybody can get promoted just by speaking endlessly without creating value for end-users. Grab has managed to create a culture where everyone wants to be promoted alone whether they make end-users happy or not. Are Grab drivers really happy? No I don't think so. If you say you are from Grab, they complain so much but they still keep you in car because of their professionalism. But the people inside Grab do not have that much professionalism.

I have known people who got promoted just by portraying themselves as experts from other top companies or just by doing worse internal products that do not really add any value to the service teams. Just for their performance review they do it. 

People who have just worked in industry for 2 or 3 years can become manager if they just express that interest and they are not evaluated whether they are managerially suitable or not. So people who report to them are screwed.  
I have known really good people leave the company because of the stupid politics.

Wanting to get promoted is not a bad thing. But if you copy Google and Amazon culture blindly, you get a culture where Gmail interface is changed just because someone wanted to get promoted and they just put billion users to relearn whatever they spent learning in Gmail interface.  There are so many improvements that can be made in Grab Food but it is not done because of promotion-centric mindset. That's why other apps in market are better to use as a customer. GrabFood is used only because of the subscription to avoid paying delivery charge.

review_title: Great Place To Work Despite Challenges
pros: My manager takes a personal interest in my development. When faced with challenges, my manager will roll up sleeves and work alongside with me to deal with the challenges. I do not feel alone. The team work spirit, collaboration and partnership is very prevalent throughout the team.
cons: Things are always changing and hence communication flow can be messy as different people receive different messages at different times.

review_title: Great opportunities at a high-growth startup
pros:
- Bosses give you autonomy to run your day-to-day tasks
- Competitive salary
- Ability to work from home or wherever you are 
- Seeing how your work contributed positively to the lives of the community (drivers and passengers)
- Colleagues and bosses became friends, we would often have after-work social activities

- Work life balance was close to zero
- Office environment (at that time) was rather dull
- Business priorities shifted all the time, which is expected of any tech unicorn

pros:

2. No answerable to anyone
3. Can take breaks as many
4. Good Pantry
cons:

3. Already change 3 head of sales and still cannot find anyone to lead!
4. Processes made but no strong leader to enfirce rules
5. Changes everydy from other departments
6. WORST COMPANY TO WORK FOR!!!!

review_title: A great place to be a better self
pros:
- supportive management teams
- fun and kind colleagues
- full of space for personal and team development
- you only need to work hard and the visibility is very high
- best tech, product, design and data team in SEA

review_title: Inspiring Leader who really walks the talk

review_title: Rampant strategy to "Manage out" employee based on convenient hearsay
pros: Ambitious founders.  Respected brand. Good branding for Resume
cons:
Some department works on "Yes man" idea. To speak out or express opinion or even defending your team members/subordinate will render one to be a rebel.

Voicing out reservations to top management will label one as being "emotional" , "petty" and "unstable". Basically falling to deaf ears.

pros:
- interesting projects to work on
- opportunity to create real impact on millions of lives in SEA
- good compensation and benefits
- flexible working hours
- nice offices / free snacks / drinks in pantry
cons:
- toxic work culture
- highly political environment
- people betray and backstab one another to get ahead
- saddest environment I have ever worked in (some colleagues are depressed)
- people work on projects to get promoted, but not to solve customer problems
- inexperienced senior leadership that didn't bother to fix serious culture problems
- employees are encouraged to speak-up and ask questions in town halls to get scripted answers that are so politically correct

pros: There’s a freedom to work remotely
cons: Poor management and communication. There seems to be zero transparency on processes, things just happen and anyone who asks why gets the answer, “this is how it’s always been done”. There’s no one-on-one culture.

pros:
At GrabTaxi, everyday is a challenge, a great opportunity for personal growth and development. 
Work is very demanding, you need to be prepared mentally to solve problems on the go. 
People here are a fun bunch. There are always beer to enjoy at anytime of the day.
cons: Too many meetings and aircon too cold.

pros: - Not much pressure, but work hours can be shortened by an hour. I see people chilling, going for smoke/tea break for an hour easily.
cons:
- Poor work culture. 
- There is a clout of oldies who are doing anything they can to maintain their powers.  No new guy is being allowed to succeed. Be it SRE, QA or service engg groups. everywhere this is rampant, those oldies group will promote people among themselves to maintain their clout power. 
- SRE/devops is the worst group here, they have not been able to ramp-up in past 3 years, they were highly in-effective in managing incidents and prod environments, that now they have moved all responsibilities to service groups(Regular engg are being turned into SREs against their wishes) and call themselves core SRE group, who don't do anything other than preaching and finding faults. 
- Grabjunior was formed and was never useful even once, and now has been killed. but everyone involved in that project has been promoted. why ? because oldies :)
- CultureAmp  surveys are a joke, there is no way for employees to rate Heads and CXOs.
- Most of the leaders here don't know anything about leadership, all culture talks are only in books, There is no talk of opportunities, goals, or anything, 1:1s never talk about growth plans, progress etc.  HR is just mute servants to these leaders. 
- 2 years exp. people are made managers of team, 3 years are made senior managers, how the F. can they manage people, what experience we are giving to their reportees ? promoting people in IC line with less exp. is still understandable, leadership takes some experience.

review_title: Great place to learn and challenge yourself

Company genuinely tries to provide good environment and benefits to employees
